caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 12.
Taira liboensis Zhu, Chen & Zhang, 2004
. A. Male habitus, dorsal view; B. Female habitus, dorsal view; C. Left male palp, prolateral view; D. Same, ventral view; E. Same, retrolateral view; F. Epigyne, ventral view; G. Same, dorsal view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. The male of this species resembles
T. obtusa
males by having a similar embolus and median apophysis ( Figs 12C–E ), but can be differentiated by the exterior dorsal tibial apophysis bifurcated in retrolateral view in
T. liboensis
, whereas not bifurcated in
T. obtusa
; and tegular apophysis triangular-shaped with a pointed end in
T. liboensis
( Figs 12C, D ), whereas almost rounded with a blunt end in
T. obtusa
. The female can be differentiated from all other
Taira species
by having reduced epigynal teeth ( Figs 12F, G ).

Description. See
Zhang et al. (2008)
. Habitus, male palp and epigyne ( Fig. 12 ).
